segments.text: Always.
For example, here we have, to give you a general view, 350,000 Greek documents from the Byzantine Empire till today.
My goodness.
Almost 13,000 Romanian documents, because the monastery was very much, after the fall of Constantinople,
the Romanian princes became the benefactors and the continuation of Byzantium.
Because Romania was a province of the Roman Empire and later of the Byzantine Empire.
And there were also Christians, the Romanians from the very first century.
Whereas the other Eastern Europeans, Slavs, Russians, Serbians, Bulgarians, not Bulgarians, Bulgarians are actually Turks.
But then they mix with the Slavs.
So the other
for example, Ukrainians, Lithuans, etc., etc., they became Christians by the Byzantines in the 11th century, beginning 10th, 11th century.
So there's continuity, and that's why they've been welcomed here.
They have their... And because of the power that the Tsar had, and also the Moldavians, the Romanian princes, the Turks didn't exterminate all the Greeks.
They could have done that and finish up the whole thing and create a new era, a new empire called Turkish Empire.
But yet Byzantium was alive, as you have seen, not only here, but also the rest of Greece, Asia Minor, Cyprus, the islands.
It was alive in the life of the people.
But they were now under this cruel domination, which unfortunately the USA supports.
very much, especially in Cyprus.
This is politics.
Put a bracket... I don't remember doing it.

My politics, I've come from Cyprus, and NATO, unfortunately, gave the blessing for the Turks to invade that little island and kill the people, etc., etc., and NATO is still giving all the force to Turkey.
Whereas for Kuwait,
The USA liberated in the night because they have interest.
For us, for Cyprus, they have other interests, so they didn't care for the people.
And we have 5,000 people killed, half the population, about 250,000 refugees even today.
And there is no light in the future.
And this is because the American policy, not the people of America, the American policy is very cruel.
It is very much directed by the Jewish lobby.
There's no joke with that.
But not the American people.
You always distinguish between the two.
I know that because I was in America for four years, and my parents were there.
And we know what people they are there, and how the policy, unfortunately.
Well, this is always for the strong nation, like Rome, which was a strong nation, to make injustice.
many times, when the Russians, the Soviets, when the Chinese, they have the power.
We have these kind of things, you know, interesting things like that.
The small people kind of survive sometimes, or they struggle.
Yeah.
We hope that the Greek people in America, who have all... Which is a very strong group, by the way.
Which is a very strong group, I know.
They're trying their best to
to create a friendly climate which we would like to have very much with the USA as well as with all the countries because we like peace.
We like peace.
Greeks were never people of war.
Only once actually they made conquering war during the Alexander time, during the times of Alexander.
Yet through his conquering he wasn't killing people unless they were very much resisting him.
Usually he was accepted and he spread
Hellenism, which eventually became a vessel for the gospel, which was written in Greek and spread in the Greek language, etc., etc.
So were people of peace, were the Turks, were people of violence, because this is how it was their culture.
They were shepherds, and then they became bandits.
And then they saw Byzantium, ooh, why don't we sit on their throne?
And they managed to do that with the help of Martin and the Western
powers, especially from the 13th century, when the Franks, Western Europeans, came and conquered Byzantium and made a big crash.
And after that, although Byzantium still was elevated in the theology, the arts, et cetera, the military was very small, and the Ottomans came and conquered the whole thing.
And that's 1453 when it fell.
They came, the Franks conquered the Crusaders, you know, the fiasco of Crusaders.
They conquered in 1204, Constantinople, and they left in 1261, and there was another two centuries of glory of Basantium, but as I said, military was very, very weak.
They lost all the provinces, and so it was easy for their Turks to come in.
And then there was no crusaders to help the Constantinople.
They lost their will for that, didn't they?
That looks like a very old trunk there.
Yes, we have many of these.
Usually here we find many, we discover many treasures.
And now I don't know whether we have anything in it.
Oh, well, we have a lot of...

maps, we are collecting all kinds of maps we have here because we have maps from the 19th, 18th century and in many languages, all kinds of languages and we know that people appreciate it very much because we have, especially after the collapse of the Soviet
Big changes, you know, with boundaries.
That's exactly right.
That is why some Americans came and they photographed the oldest geography of Ptolemy, which we have here, which I will show you.
And they photographed the whole thing.
And then two weeks, the three small Lithuania, Estonia, and Letonia,
they make a revolution.
And many of the fathers here say, hmm, there might be something there CIA perhaps.
Who knows?
Who knows?
Anyway, so these are the Romanian archives, which are now studied by a Rumanologist, as we call him.
He's a professor in Athens.
He's half Greek and Romanian.
and he lives in Athens for many years with two of his graduate students.
They're making a very good work.
They are now translating them in modern Greek and of course then we have to have them in English for all the experts.
The language usually is either Slavic or Romanian or
And some of them, some of them, which we included in the Romanian archive, they come even from Tsars.
But we said, let's put together, since they are Flavonics and Romanian, let's make them one team.
But because most of it, the majority are Romanian, from princes of, around the principalities of Danube.
Before Romania became a big country, last century, it was
Transylvania, Moldavia, and Vlahia.
And these three principalities were very much helping these monasteries, especially, as well as other monasteries, but very much these monasteries.
That is why the Romanians, they don't have their own monastery.
They have three skates, but they don't have their own monastery, yet for them, Vatopelli is their own monastery.
And you can see the continuation of this tradition.
We have six Romanian fathers in the monastery.
Here's six.
Okay.
And many others who want to come.
Now here are documents, documents, documents.
Also documents which are more contemporary with the so-called metohia.
Metohia is a word for properties which were given as a gift by pious Christians to monasteries in order so that it will become a source of

income for the monks since the monks cannot work outside and have their own money since they are dealing with praying and worshipping God and things like that in order to help them to have people come and work and build or do other things to find source of income I used people to reach and grow up they used to give the land or they used to give a lake or
animals, houses, real estate, things like that.
And these are the deeds, the documents.
Exactly.
Unfortunately, many are lost.
Because they go back many, many centuries.
Also because of the so-called catastrophe of Hellenism in Minor Asia.
We still call it Minor Asia, as you can see.
in 1922, when the Turks eliminated almost all the Greeks, killing them or just sending them away when they came to Greece.
These people, thousands and thousands of people, came here without anything.
I went to a village outside of Ephesus last week, a beautiful little village, and up on the top of the hill are two Greek churches.
And they're abandoned, and there isn't a single Greek in the town.
The churches are still there.
But I said, gee, are there any Greeks around?
Not the Greek community of God.
The prophets are saying that pretty soon, since the Turkish nation was established of blood, it's going to be wiped out with blood.
It's the divine justice which balances and controls everything.

And so we know people who have told us, Turks, who have told us that when the feast of that travel, which is completely deserted, and there are no Greeks around the area, in the night we see lights and we hear chanting.
We go there and we see nothing.
We come back again, we see the same thing.
This is a proof that Vizatim is still alive there.
And...
One of the reasons why the Turks are so aggressive is because they know that they are not in their own house.
They're sitting on somebody else's seat.
That makes them nervous, as you know.
It should.
So here, as we see, documents, document, documents.
So this is now the second floor?
This is the basement.
Oh, this is the basement.
This is the one we were... The first, then we're going to go to the second and the third.
There is a top floor.
Yes, our grandfather Joseph the Hissihast, who I mentioned.
Yes.
And he is the root, our Abraham, of our, of Vatoperi, Dionysiu, Philotheou Caracallou Custamonitou, Xyropotamou, six, yes.
What are his dates, his years?
He lived between, he was born in 1898 in the island of Paros and died in 1959 at the New Skit on the other side of the office with our father Joseph also, Joseph of Vatateri.
Do you have one?
a hospital?
I'll show you.
It's next to this tower.
Sorry, you don't have to show me.
I just wondered if monks get sick.
We had a hospital here because the monastery was big and people from the cells could come here or from the skits and we still also today there were always some monks who knew medicine.
They could apply to that.
Of course today we have
development in medicine.
It's going to return.
They are changing the... We have generators.
And we use them.
We use different monies, different denies.
It depends also on what we are working.
It's a big monastery, one kilometer perimetre.
We have discovered in manuscripts 8,800 monks in Byzantine times.
And now we are doing the monastery in such a... So you discovered eight hundred monks... Eight hundred, but there were times that there were hundreds of monks here, even eight hundred.
As many as... As many as eight hundred, exactly, in the Byzantine times.
And from this monastery Hilandara came, because the Serbian king Simeon and his son Prince Savas, the two greatest saints of Serbia, of the Serbian church, became monks here.
Whereas their queen became a nun in Serbia.
And then an influx of Serbian monks followed them.
And they wanted to make their own monastery.
And Vatopedi gave them a property of their own.
And they made Hilandar.
And so Hilandar is a daughter of Vatopedi.
Also, we lost many of these properties.
I didn't finish it in 1922 when we gave it to all these refugees.
Especially we had a lot of property in Khalkidiki.
The area around, you know, Cassandra, the Three Legs, and around Thessalonica, all this area.
And we had many properties, and the fathers, due to the emergency, they just gave the whole land to the people.
The government promised to give us money, and we're still waiting for it.
You know, we governments.
Every government when it comes to money.
You did that on the way down.
I should have warned you.
No, that's fine.
I've got a strong head.
I have.
In my first year, when I became a monk here, I so many times bumped my head.
And if you used to be... Let's hold on here today.
Yes, sir.
You can sit on the items.
Look at these.
Marvelous, sir.
Yes, it is.
Oh, yes.
And even here, you will see also... I have a question for you, Father.
Are these inscribed pieces of stone, are they considered manuscripts?
Not manuscripts, are they considered documents in a way?
Yes, of course, because they are giving us information on writing.
It doesn't have to be papyrus and parchment, it might be marble.
This is pertinent to my new book as well, because I'm dealing with technology, the changing nature of information transmission.
For example, over here you see,
These are from Hellenistic, even classical Athens, 4th century BC, the death, the mourning of the dead lord of the house.
And this is a sign, a symbol that his life has finished and he's going to another life.

Because the ancient Greeks saw that man, in order to add a few things to what Father Athenius didn't say to you, they saw that man has conscience, choosing, willingness, memory, and many other things that animals possess.
they realize that these things are things that are qualities of an emotional being.
And that is why this means, according to an expert who told us a few years ago, his life on the earth is finished and he's going into another one.
So are these here because they're beautiful or because they transmit information?
It's because the fathers discovered them here and there.
There were six good scenes on Athos
according to historians like Herodotus and others, which you will find in books.
So this goes back to classical and Hellenic.
Classical and Romans.
You can see Roman times as well.
And these were found here.
Yes, they were found here, and we placed them here.
Lately, just a few weeks ago, we discovered big jars in our garden while we were at Ford.
Yes, something like that, bacon, amphores.
Pythos is more than amphores, you know, it's something like this, but we're talking about huge... It's just salmon after all these centuries.
Yes, from the Hellenistic time, according to the expert who came here.
And so now we're not going to use that for the garden.
We're making new plantations because we're becoming more and more people, more and more guests, and we want to have
you know, using organic gardening and things like that, and we want to expand.
But every now and then we discover something archaeological.
Who are the guys, the monks?
The monks, ourselves, and of course we have some workers who are coming now from the ex-Soviet Union.
Do they live here in Athos?
They live with us, and if they behave, they stay with us.
Sometimes they don't, they get kicked out.
It's not easy to stay, especially for young men, to stay in a place where there's no TV entertainment.
Let's just leave it at that.
There are a few, though, who are clever, and they become baptized here, because although their countries were traditionally orthodox due to communism, they were above them.
And look how strongly orthodoxists come back to Russia.
I was told...
Two, three years ago, by some priests who are also professors in the Academy of St.
Sergius in Moscow, 400 monasteries in a few years have been filled with monks and nuns.
And they are making more and more and more and more.
Can you describe briefly some of the things that are here?
Yes.
Here we have a couple of showcases in order to demonstrate to the people, representatively if I may say so,
Here we have from our collection which we said is 2050 manuscripts.
By the way we are still discovering manuscripts.
Now where do you discover them when you say you discover them?
We are discovering because we may discover it when an old father from the previous world who dies, he has many books.
We go and we collect the books and half of the book is handwritten.
Or a book is a pure manuscript of the 17th century, of the 16th century.

we may discover while looking at the books we are newcomers by the way only eight years in this monastery only eight years now who's newcomers now we we were at the the brotherhood was at the new street where joseph de hisi has died i see and then became about 15 20 people and then they were asked to come here because there were only few old monks here in the 60s in 63
we had the millennium of Monathos, actually the millennium of Lavra, but they said of the whole Monathos.

And the people who came here, many prestigious people, patriarchs, kings, etc., they were saying that we're actually doing the funeral of Monathos, because there were only less... During the funeral of this?
Yes, they were also doing the funeral of this, quote-unquote, because there were less than 700 monks,
And the average age was 60 years old, something like that.
This was of all of us?
Yes, that was of all of us.
So it was down to 700.
700, and the age was very... And this is in the 60s?
In the 60s.
It's about 2,000 now, isn't it?
Now it's 2,000, and the average age, as you have seen, is...
25, may I say?
I wrote this down four times in my notebook today, how young these men are.
You will find young men in monasteries, if you go like, for example, see Monopetra, Grigoriou, the monastery that you will see, Vion, Lavra, you will see a lot of young people.
So you say the new brotherhood, you came from which?
From the new skeet.
It's a skeet which belongs to the monastery of St.
Paul.
And that is where St.
Joseph de Hesihas... And it's called the New Skeet.
New Skeet.
That's its name.
New.
N-E-W.
New.
Something which is new.
Because it was newer than the other ones.
And it was at the... It's near St.
Paul's Monastery on the other side of the peninsula.
There St.
Joseph de Hesihas died in 59.
And one of his students, our Joseph, the Vatopendian,
made his own brotherhood, and eventually they came here.
And they assumed, not assumed, but they... The Patriot for Santinople.
And the Holy Community, which is the government of the Lord Athos, decided to bestow the power to the new brotherhood of Father Joseph of Antipati.
because the old monks were unable to run these monasteries.
There were about 10 and they were 70 years old, many of them.
Now we have only two of them.
All of them are gone.
They died.
And this is really responsible for this dynamic.
It sent Joseph to the Hissi house.
as well as his energiosity.
But the attitude that is... They projected this whole dynamism is the word you used earlier.
Yes, dynamismos.
It's something, and the statistics, as I said before, about the millennium and the funeral, etc., they said that you are doing the funeral.
Well, Athos we should, maybe, the Junta in 67 was thinking to

pull all the monks in one monastery, one of the big monasteries maybe, and turn the rest of the monasteries, museums, hotels, things like that, and make it a forest for hunting for their royalties and for the VIPs and the presidents of the countries and things like that.
But they didn't count that there is a lady here, a governess.
A woman.
A Virgin Mary, the only woman who can come here.
From the 70s,
Suddenly, we have a reverse.
The hunter is gone.
The hunter is gone, yes.
Number one.
Number one.
The thing is that young men, most of them, the graduates, professionals, they came with having full knowledge of what they were going to do.
Sacrifice their whole life and their whole personality in order to come here and service God.
in the church.
Did the Junta really seriously propose doing this?
It was one of the ideas.
They tossed it out?
Yeah, so to speak, they tossed it out.
Just to see, like we call it a trial balloon, see how people respond.
Let's see how people respond, exactly.
Also, others was, we had also another thing.
A gentleman came, I remember, some years ago, and he said to the fathers here, I would like to make a hotel here,
and I can give you a lot of money, and we can make it a special hotel, Byzantine hotel, you know, things like that.
See, they don't understand.
But they don't understand what's going on here.
It's like we say back home, they don't get it.
Even the people in Greece, they didn't understand Mao's house.
Because there was this disruption due to the Turkish occupation, ignorance,
There was a turn towards the technology and science of Western Europe.
So what attracts the special person who comes here?
Divine grace.
You answered that immediately.
Nothing else.
Because if it is not divine, there is nothing else for us here.
We have no money, no property, no pleasures, no our own family, which is something very natural.
We didn't hate our family and we came here.
You loved yourself.
We loved them and we prayed for them more than we would do outside.
And they have benefited most of them.
Usually the first people who benefit are relatives, spiritually speaking.
And we came out of love for God and His Mother.
And we stay here because they provide us divine grace.
The energies of the Holy Spirit.
Because here, as you can see, we wake up at 3.30.
And we work without being paid.
There's no vacations.
We cannot travel or do whatever we like without the permission of the abbot.
And, of course, by being obedient, that doesn't mean that we have lost our freedom.
No, we are seeking freedom, the spiritual freedom, the freedom from our passion.
Look at the freedom that people are talking about today.
They say, I want to be free.
Do whatever I like.
You're doing whatever your passion is telling you to do, usually.
Here we're trying to halt this passion.
How long have you welcomed pilgrims like myself to come?
Have you always welcomed people to come?
Of course.
Because the people built the monasteries together with the kings.
The people give the taxation and the people came and worked for this.
Of course the kings were the overseers and they make the plans and the decisions and things like that.
But the people... So it belongs to the people?
It belongs to the Orthodox people.
Obviously.
Obviously.
But also to the rest of the people because we welcome anyone who might come here.
And as you can see, we have fathers here who were non-orthodox, became orthodox here, and then became monks.
And also we have a lot of foreigners, let's call them foreigners, because we don't like this.
We see humanity as one.
Like Adam was one family.
We are actually one family.
And especially after Christ came here from Pentecost, we are one.
Okay, I am Greek and he is...
Italian, and he's Russian, and he's English, etc., etc., but, and other attributes, the language, and other differences, but we have one common thing, faith.
And this is a model here, please underline, model, of a republic, a real republic.
We are so many people, 2,000 people, coming from all kinds of countries, even from Brazil, Chile, let me think, another...
remote place, like England, or like Africa, just name it, Australia, Africa.
Do you have some black people here?

They don't stay with us, they go back to continue their missionary work, but they come to us, Orthodox, from Africa, and they spend time with us, they become priests, then they go back and they continue their work, they build churches, parishes, even communities, monastic communities lately.
since we have a revival here on Athens.
And now all these people are together, they are different in so many things, yet they have one common thing, faith, the gospel.
And because of that, they are united.
Of course, you will hear, ah, we have chorus.
Okay, in every family we have chorus and differences, things like that.
But still, whatever differences might be, we are all well together.

Someone may say, yes, but you have a Russian monastery, and you have a Bulgarian monastery, and you have a Serbian monastery, and you have Romanian skits, and Iviro was Georgian, Iviro, Georgian actually, it was, now it's, I, it's, people there who live up mostly weeks.
Yes, these are historical reasons.
It's because of the Turkish occupation, and they wanted to make it strong in order to be
not to have a dominion, the Turkish rule.
But as you can see in our monastery now, we have a mosaic of people.
And this is happening in other monasteries, if you visit them.
When you go to Trivia, you will find a British.
If you go to see Monogatari, you will find French and Germans.
If you go in, let me think, here, you will find Romanians, Brazilians, the Czech.
Of course, the majority is still Greek.
Because, as we said before, somehow God has given the leadership to the Greeks.
And I'm not saying this out of Shoveghism.
It's God's plan, as He worked in the very beginning with the people of Israel, then the succession of the apostles was with fathers.
And they were, of course, also called Romans only, because they became all of the Roman sinners.
Because Romans or Greeks was the same thing.
There was a distinction.
The distinction was made later on for politics, with the theism and things like that.
Behind this is politics.
So there are Charles Marlous, you know, the Holy Roman Empire.
They tried to make an empire so that their real Roman Empire, Byzantium, would be slowly, slowly wiped out.
And Roman Catholicism came up.
It didn't happen, thank goodness.
So, let's go back to some of these.
Okay, here we have a few from our collection.
This is a geography of Ptolemy.
It was taken out in the exhibition in Celerica last year.
It is the oldest copy.
The original was done, of course, as you know better than I do, in the second century BC in Alexandria by Ptolemy.
And this copies the oldest, 13th century.
And the monk used the, in order to draw all the maps, he used the, I don't know how you call it in English, the parameters, the numberings of the globe.
Meridians.
Meridians, parameters.
Longitude, latitude.
That's it, that's it.
I understand what you mean.
I don't remember this one.
I have to look at the dictionary.
So he did it, and as you can see, it is very... We have just printed it, by the way.
Sufeximoid copies, yes.
Yes, we have made also a copy, which I don't know whether we are sending this, because it was just been published a few days ago.
And here you can see Middle East.
since the Orient has somehow the beginning of the civilization, we usually have this page.
This was in the Thessaloniki exhibit.
Exactly.
From... what was it?
It was August of... I bought the book, so it'll be in there.
Okay.
It has about... how many maps?
Of the three continents.
That's fine, yeah.
You know, North America or...
It's not known yet.
I don't remember the number of the maps.
Is it 40?
You will find it in the book.
I have the book.
You have the book, okay.
And we have everything there, except two pages written.
The British stole them.
But they're in the British Museum, and in our edition, we added these two pages.
And now we're about to make an exhibition worldwide, which we haven't talked.
We will talk about that later on, because I'm going to give you a lot of information.
It wouldn't be the right time to tell you about this.
We're going to have an exhibition, maybe even in New York.
Really?
Yes, with things from here.
Is Vatopedi or apples?
Vatopedi.
Vatopedi, as well as relics from Vatopedi, which are now in museums and libraries in the whole world, like Dabarton, Ongs, the mosaic portable icon of St.
John Chrysostom, or like a lot of, in Moscow, Hermitage,
That was a landmark.

So we're going to bring those which are outside of Adoferi, and now we're trying our best, it's not easy, this is in the process, to get also a few from here, but a few and very special, very, very special.
Remarkable.
Which haven't been exposed.
And where was this done?
This was done in the 13th century, and by a monk, as I said.
Here?
Here.
The second part of this
codex is the geographical information by Strabon, who lived in the first century AD.
He was a Cretan, but he lived in Rome.
That's why most people think that he's Latin, but he was a Cretan.
No, I know him.
I quote him in my book, which I'm sending out.
And so here you have a perfect geography of antiquity and medieval times for military purposes.
for governmental purposes, etc., etc.
It is very, very important.
Unbelievable.
Here from the same century, 13th century, the first eight books of the Old Testament, and it's called Okta Tefk.
Okta Tefk.
You know this.
It's a term.
Beautiful illuminations, 153 miniatures.
How many miniatures?
It is all, I think this is also in the book.
If it is not, you will write to me and I will give you additional information because now I don't have everything in my head.
And we have the text and commentaries by the Fathers and beautiful illumination, 700 years old, and you can see how beautiful they are.
This is probably the most beautiful illustrated manuscript of our collection of manuscripts here.
No, in this book, the Octateth, you would suggest is the most beautiful.
Yes, this is not only my own experience, it's also I've heard experts, Byzantinologists who came here, and they said, this is magnificent.
I can't remember.
Maybe.
But this will be in the book I've got today.
Yes.
If it's not in the one book, it's going to be in the other.
But I think also that one went out.
I think so.
We send a lot of relics because we have so many.
We were quite rich in that.
Now, 11th century, four Gospels.
Tetra Evangelion.
Tetra, cuatro, four.
11th century.
Here you can see also beautiful miniature of Mark.
And here is the beginning of the Gospel.
Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
That's gold with lapis lazuli.
This is 900 years old.
They were using and believing.
We have some other cosmos with absolutely so perfect manuscripts that you would say, this is childish.
Believe me.
But I cannot take you there.
It's a treasury and you have to have the board has to sign and things like that.
Maybe next time... Everything takes time.
You know, it will cooperate more and more.
You will gain the trust of the boat here, and they will give you... I totally understand.
And they will ask you to go there.
This is a great treat right here.
I am grateful for everything that you're doing now.
I believe that the Virgin has brought you here.
I can see some more things behind all this.
I can see the blessing of the Virgin to you and to your family.
You probably have some artists up there who wanted you to come here.
I think so.
It was my first choice, you know.
I was in the square yesterday and they were talking about the close monasteries.
And I just said, I want to go to Vagopedi first.
They said, but that's too far away.
Nobody would drive me out here.
Yes, it's due to the sea with the rock.
I stayed in a little monastery near the square and then I came out this morning.
But here we are.
So it's...
It was quite strange how we left together, you know.
You were there.
And you know, at that time, on Sundays, I'm never out of my cell.
